Trial_Design.evidence: Patients were randomly assigned to receive 30 mg of low-molecular-weight heparin (enoxaparin) twice daily or 81 mg of aspirin twice daily for thromboprophylaxis.

Participants.evidence: We included adult patients with an operatively treated extremity fracture or a pelvic or acetabular fracture.

Intervention.evidence: Patients were randomly assigned to receive 30 mg of low-molecular-weight heparin (enoxaparin) twice daily or 81 mg of aspirin twice daily for thromboprophylaxis.

Objective.evidence: To understand patients’ experiences with these medications, we compared patients’ satisfaction and out-of-pocket costs after thromboprophylaxis with aspirin versus low-molecular-weight heparin.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The study outcomes included patient satisfaction with and out-of-pocket costs for their thromboprophylactic medication measured on ordinal scales.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Patients were randomly assigned to receive 30 mg of low-molecular-weight heparin (enoxaparin) twice daily or 81 mg of aspirin twice daily for thromboprophylaxis.

Number_Randomised.evidence: The trial enrolled 12,211 patients (mean age and standard deviation [SD], 45 ± 18 years; 62% male)

Number_Analysed.evidence: 9725 of whom completed the question regarding their satisfaction with the medication and 6723 of whom reported their out-of-pocket costs.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The odds of greater satisfaction were 2.6 times higher for patients assigned to aspirin than those assigned to low-molecular-weight heparin (odds ratio [OR]: 2.59; 95% confidence interval [CI]: 2.39 to 2.80; p < 0.001).
